Description:
Part of a stupa drum panel with two incomplete scenes, one showing an ascetic with other figures and the other the Buddha and a drummer. From right to left an emaciated and bearded ascetic with prominent ribs and indrawn abdomen above a short animal-skin lower garment, bent legs and bowed posture, stands looking upwards, his left arm ending in a damaged hand, probably holding a broken staff. Above him a half-length figure with a crested turban, necklace and an uttarīya looks down, while beside him, seen from the back, strides a younger figure with a chignon and hair curled at the neck, an uttarīya, a paridhāna, earrings and a bracelet, his head raised like the ascetic's and his movement emphasised by the relief of his rounded and asymmetrical buttocks under the clinging garment.
In the next scene a muscular and turbaned figure, wearing a paridhāna and an uttarīya perhaps tied round and hanging down from the waist, a bracelet, an earring and a collar, raises one hand to strike the barrel drum hanging from his left shoulder and further held below by his left hand as he turns to the Buddha. The taller Buddha stands almost frontally but with his damaged head towards the drummer, his left hand, now lost, was perhaps covered in the prominently and regularly ridged over-robe and his lost right hand originally no doubt performed the abhaya gesture. Between Buddha and drummer a turbaned half-length figure with collar and earring looks at the Buddha.
Separating the scenes a framed and neatly tapering column with a Corinthian capital stands on a squat pot base rather than one of the usual type. The panel is framed above by a sawtooth cornice and a plain fillet below.
Dimensions: Diameter: 5 centimetres; Height: 17.10 centimetres; Width: 27.30 centimetres
Curators Comments:
Zwalf 1996:
In the first scene, which may have shown one or more ascetics facing the Buddha, the striding figure is not easily explained. The second scene could be classed with Foucher's
group with drummer representing, with or without a gateway as he later thought, the Entry into Rājagṛha. In the legend episodes with the Kāśyapa ascetics and the visit to Rājagṛha occur close together soon after the Enlightenment. Foucher defines his Entry into Rājagṛha from the Pāli canon as the Buddha and his monks coming for a meal at the invitation of king Bimbisāra when Indra, as a young brāhmaṇa, much admired for his looks, led the way singing verses. A meeting with King Bimbisāra and another with Uruvilva Kāśyapa and the king's invitation to a meal are generally reported at this stage in versions of the legend but while there can also be mention of a messenger (Saṃghabhedavastu) there is none of a musical escort except in the Pāli.
Bib references: Zwalf 1996 / A Catalogue of the Gandhara Sculpture in the British Museum
Condition:
1.Grey schist, broken, chipped and with soil incrustation. 
2.Top and bottom, where undamaged, flat and smooth; 'J' incised on top; on left, vestiges of cramp mortise; sides irregularly broken. 
3.Back with vertical chisel grooves. 
4.Curved in section.

Description:
Panel showing the Death of the Buddha. 
The Buddha is here more frontal than in the preceding piece, his feet are covered and his right knee is flexed forward; his robe, over both shoulders and covering his left hand, has regular curving and rounded ridges for drapery folds. The wavy hair continues into the uṣṇīṣa. His face is long and oval; the lids of the closed eyes meet in a slit. Under his right hand is a full pillow with a bobble, the side of the mattress has an undulating groove and a textile hangs between the turned legs with a wide pleat in the middle.
In front of the couch a monk, perhaps Ānanda, his right shoulder bare, supports himself on the ground with one hand and stretches out the other. Beside him, turned almost in profile, an apparently meditating figure, presumably Subhadra, with wrapped head and both shoulders covered, corresponds to the seated frontal figure in the same position in BM 1889.0715.9. The monk at the head of the bed, Anuruddha, with a bare right shoulder, visible undergarment and concerned expression, the tonsure lacking a hairline, advances towards Ānanda and probably extended an undercut arm now missing; his left arm is flexed indistinctly with the hand to, or above, the shoulder. Beside him Vajrapāṇi, a grieving old man with a broad chest, raises one arm over and across his head, which is turned away from the Buddha. He wears a short paridhāna and his uttarīya knotted as a thick scarf over his thighs, and his legs are undercut. His face is distinctly, almost finely, featured and two rows of curls over his lined forehead cover an otherwise bald head. The faceted vajra in his left hand lies against his shoulder. Above Vajrapāṇi is a tree with evenly paired leaves on the narrow curving branches and above the monk a mourner, both arms raised and ornamented, notably with armlets beside the shoulder, and wearing a small chignon and an uttarīya, looks on in grief.
Behind the Buddha is a damaged figure on rather a larger scale than the others. He has a broad flat chest under a large damaged head with earrings and short curls dramatically thrown back; he brings his undercut arms, with armlets just beside the shoulders, together behind his head; his eyes are long, open and set above high cheek-bones. To his left two figures, ornamented and with uttarīya, one with a high crested turban, the other with arms folded and possibly a chignon over a short hairstyle with a curled border, appear to be in conversation; another figure, in particular relief, turbaned and ornamented and with a grief-stricken face, brings one hand to the side of his head. Behind them are damaged half-length figures. On the flowering tree with narrowing trunk the lower branches are undercut.
Below the tree two figures converse: a monk almost in profile, right shoulder bare and an undergarment visible above undercut legs, a small 'embonpoint' below a broken arm, faces another figure with his right hand lifted, an undergarment also visible but his over-robe, which leaves the right shoulder bare, covering the gently inclined head, the backthrow passing round the neck. In the figure with a draped head and usually a bundle of sticks and talking with a monk in scenes of the Death cycle Foucher supposed that an ascetic of the tridaṇḍa-carrying order had replaced, in announcing the Buddha's death to Mahākāśyapa, the naked ājīvika of the piece in the previous catalogue entry, but in certain scenes learning of the circumstances before meeting Mahākāśyapa. For the monastic figures see also BM 1899.0715.9.
Dimensions: Diameter: 8.40 centimetres; Height: 23.80 centimetres; Width: 35 centimetres
Curators Comments:
Zwalf 1996:
This panel contrasts with BM 1899.0715.9 in detail and delicacy, rounded cutting, composition and proportions.
The damaged figure behind the Buddha is perhaps a deity; other instances of a mourner, of large and energetic appearance, are seen elsewhere and also behind the bed among the gesturing Mallas or deities. On Peshawar 2084 a central figure with similar gesture has whiskers and an unusual headdress (turban). On Lahore 1037 a prominent central figure is the yakṣa Vajrapāṇi, but the corresponding figure on Peshawar 775 has a turban and an uttarīya. For the size of the head see the same feature on Swat Butkara 2892 (Faccenna-Taddei, 1962-4: II, pl. CDXIII) where, under the Bodhisattva's horse and between its hind legs, a yakṣa has a huge head, voluminous hair and moustache; and if this is an albeit occasional feature of a yakṣa, perhaps the figure here is another example.

Title: The Descent from the Trāyastriṃśa heaven at Sāṃkāśya. (Object)
Description:
Trapezoidal panel, probably from a vertical series, showing the Descent from the Trāyastriṃśa heaven at Sāṃkāśya. The haloed central Buddha, head now missing, stands frontally with his over-robe covering both shoulders, the neckline curved and in higher relief, the drapery folds shown in regular ridges. His abhaya gesture is all but lost. He stands in the middle on a triple stair of two treads, the central stair facing the viewer, the two flanking at an angle with the risers sloping inwards. Beside the Buddha on the flanking stairs are Indra on his left and Brahmā, both with hands joined and in uttarīya and paridhāna, Indra with ornaments. Brahmā's hair is long under a chignon with a horizontal length of hair with one end looped and one hanging down onto the forehead. Beside him at ground level two similar figures of diminishing size, hands joined, share his simpler appearance; those occupying the upper part of the panel wear ornaments and one is about to throw flowers, another has a bag at the waist from which he prepares to extract flowers, and between them a small Vajrapāṇi with a chignon to one side holds a short vajra. Kneeling beneath Brahmā and beside the central stair a figure with a bare right shoulder, a long garment and hands joined must be the nun Utpalavarṇa. Indra, on the Buddha's left, joins his hands and wears an uttarīya looped in higher relief below the waist, a bracelet, a collar, earrings and a headdress which combines a turban of cross-hatched pattern with a cylindrical top and vertical jewelled bands. Beside him two figures of diminishing size with hands joined, collars, bracelets and an uttarīya, one of whom wears a crested turban, the other a double-looped chignon, balance the pair opposite. Above them, variously disposed, three half-length figures in uttarīya and the usual ornaments, two with a crested turban and one with wavy hair, balance the three opposite; two are about to throw large handfuls of flowers while one joins his hands.
The panel is framed at the bottom by a plain fillet and at the sides by a moulding with a cross-hatched pattern rising from a pot-shaped faceted terminal like a chain from a jeweller's mount.
Production place: Made in: Gandhara (Pakistan);  Made in: Pakistan (?)
Dimensions: Diameter: 6.40 centimetres; Height: 32.10 centimetres; Width: 44.70 centimetres
Curators Comments:
Zwalf 1996:
After the Buddha had taught his mother and the gods in the Trāyastriṃśa heaven, he returned to Jambudvīpa, surrounded by gods, at Sāṃkāśya and there was a magnificent display of men, gods and of a cakravartin magically created by (the nun) Utpalavarṇā. The tradition that he came down on a central ladder flanked by Indra and Brahmā, each on his own ladder, and accompanied by deities, is, with variations, found in Pāli and sources of northern origin. Usually in the texts Brahmā's ladder is of silver and Indra's of jewels and they are on the right and left respectively; the monuments seem to agree that these positions are with reference to the Buddha. At their foot the Buddha was greeted, in the Pāli tradition, by Śāriputra and Utpalavarṇā.
For a version perhaps without stairs see BM 1917.1009.11.

Description:
Stupa drum panel with two scenes, each showing the Buddha and a couple. In the right-hand scene the Buddha, towering over all other figures, has to his left Vajrapāṇi, and above and between them is a half-length onlooker in a crested turban. The damaged Vajrapāṇi holds his right hand to his hip and the vajra vertically in his left hand and appears to be looking up at the Buddha. His torso is muscular, his arms and legs very slender and his short lower garment is densely pleated and hangs with a thick excess of cloth between the legs. The Buddha's over-robe, covering both shoulders, apparently conceals his hands; he stands, head lowered, right hand raised to touch that of the striding male figure who, as he advances, holds up a flower or flowers; he is seen from the back and the head, hair clearly short, looks upwards and sideways over the left shoulder. He wears a uttarīya and paridhāna. A young woman, wearing ornaments, stands turned towards him, her right wrist perhaps held by the male figure, while her left hand brings its index finger to her mouth. She wears a garment passing over her left shoulder, a paridhāna round it and a scarf draped round the elbows as it falls from the headdress, which seems to consist of a wreath with a flower to the front and a coil and loop of hair above it. Beside her, almost full-length save for the legs, is a spectator or deity with long hair in a chignon and an uttarīya worn wrapped round the right arm.
In the incomplete scene a male figure kneels, one knee only on the ground which the head, showing a chignon, almost touches, back curved and wearing only a paridhāna, in front of a woman who appears to emerge from a doorway oblique to the scene, hands joined, dressed like the woman in the right-hand scene except for the single wreath of her headdress. A third figure, wearing an uttarīya and a turban with a crest on its side, turns beside the door towards the tall Buddha who appears almost compressed between the upper and lower frames, his head inclined and his damaged right hand held across the body while his left hangs free of the garment. Above the doorway is an ornamental cornice of lotus petals pointing upwards, but the architraves are too worn to show clearly whether they have ornament.
The framed columns have the usual base and a Corinthian capital in distinct upper and lower parts. Above is a sawtooth cornice and below a plain framing fillet.
Dimensions: Diameter: 4.90 centimetres; Height: 17 centimetres; Width: 46.70 centimetres
Curators Comments:
Zwalf 1996:
The eyes of the figures are shown as rounded and protruding, except for those of the Buddha which are thin narrow slits between lids. Noteworthy are the naturalistic treatment of Vajrapāṇi's torso and the bold use of the partial back view in the right-hand scene.
It is tempting to see here perhaps a rare Dīpaṃkara sequence in two successive and separate frames as against the preponderance of representations using continuous narration. The transactions with the Buddha and the young woman are, however, obscure, and the young male appears to lack a chignon in the first scene and might be thought, if he were Megha, to have loosened his hair in the second where it still seems short. Compare BM 1880.68, 1980.0225.1, 1880.208, 1899.0715.11 and 1892.0801.7. Identification must remain in doubt, although the two scenes may well be connected.
In an early photograph this fragment seems to be in the same condition as now and appears together with BM 1880.103. For their connection with Lahore 820 and Chandigarh 730 see Errington, 1987a: 340-2, and figs 199-201. The present and following pieces appear to fit the same circumference (c 4.75 m) and show similarities of treatment, especially of the male in three-quarter view with mannered prominence of his buttocks, but the difference in the base of the divider column in the following piece is noteworthy. Apart from the common features, there seems no obvious connection of subject between the four.

Title: The Death of the Buddha. (Object)
Description:
Panel showing the Death of the Buddha. Lying on his side, head turned to his right and feet away from each other, the Buddha holds his right hand, apparently emerging from the high neckline, as if in abhaya below his head and against the bordered halo. His left hand is covered by the robe, which continues in pleats below it. The hair is wavy into the uṣṇīṣa, the long oval face has partly open, expressionless eyes. The pillow under and behind the halo has bobbles at the corners, the top of the bed is covered in a textile which hangs between the turned legs with, in the middle, an ornamental scroll down to the footstool. Beside the bed sits a small meditating monk, frontal and in low relief, his robe lying spread in a straight edge below the damaged hands.
At the head of the bed a youthful Vajrapāṇi, his uttarīya plunging below his loincloth, raises his right arm, while his left holds a vajra vertically at shoulder level. Behind the bed stand four figures, each with a crested turban, collar, bracelet, earrings and, save one, an uttarīya; two appear in conversation, one of these raising his hand with the index and middle fingers pointing upwards together and the thumb perhaps extended, while another, also with a long necklace, raises both arms. At the foot of the bed a naked tonsured figure holds a flower in one hand, but the other hand, across the abdomen, seems unfinished; he talks with a monk in three garments, whose right hand with raised index and middle fingers joined makes almost the same gesture as above. These are presumably Mahākāśyapa and an ājīvika. Above them the tree has long narrow branches with evenly paired leaves; behind Vajrapāṇi the trunk is damaged.
A plain fillet frames the bottom of the panel.
Dimensions: Height: 30.40 centimetres on base ; Height: 27.20 centimetres sculpture only ; Weight: 20 kilograms; Width: 44.30 centimetres; Depth: 9.70 centimetres base ; Depth: 8.90 centimetres sculpture only
Curators Comments:
Zwalf 1996:
The features are sharply, if clumsily, carved, the faces sometimes heavy, the noses prominent and broad and the mouths set back between jowls.
The Indian texts agree substantially over the Buddha's last days. He became seriously ill near Vaiśālī but was able to reach the Malla country, near Kuśinagara, where Cunda, the smith, prepared him the mysterious sūkaramaddava which again made him ill. Proceeding to Kuśinagara, he lay down on his right side between two sāla trees, his head to the north, and the trees flowered unseasonably. Ānanda attended, grieving, gods assembled and the Mallas of Kuśinagara were summoned, coming in great numbers. The ascetic Subhadra was the Buddha's last convert. When the Buddha was dead, Brahmā, Indra and the monk Anuruddha (Aniruddha) recited verses, monks grieved and the Mallas came to honour his body. They could not lift it for the cremation until Anuruddha had indicated the gods' wishes and it would not burn until Mahākāśyapa, informed on the road by an ājīwika, had arrived with his followers and it then caught fire spontaneously. The Mallas took possession of the remains and would yield none to claimants among the neighbouring tribes who prepared to fight, until a brāhmaṇa had effected a peaceable division; then each erected a stupa in his own territory to enshrine a share.
In representations of the Great Decease the usually haloed Buddha lies invariably on his right side, his covered left hand down his side, the right palm outwards beside the head; a leg can be flexed and the drapery may hang as on a standing figure. The bed, with turned or carved legs, may have a mattress and pillow and a textile, sometimes decorated, hanging between the legs; a small stool also occurs. At each side one of the traditional pair of sāla is represented by a tree, commonly with evenly paired leaves on the branches, and there may be more. Attendants may include Brahmā and Indra, usually Vajrapāṇi, figures indistinguishably gods or Mallas unless, as in Calcutta 5147, they are half-length and flying figures and throwing flowers, and monks identified as Ananda, Anuruddha and Mahākāśyapa. Vajrapāṇi stands at the head of the bed as here and in the following piece, or behind it, or lies beside it, raising one arm in a gesture of grief or holding it across the top of his head. Usually at the foot of the bed is a figure with a wrapped head and a triple staff (tridaṇḍa) or a monk with or without monastic staff, the monk sometimes touching the Buddha's feet or in conversation with a naked and tonsured figure, while the figure with the triple staff, the tridaṇḍin, may be talking with a monk behind or beside the couch. To explain this confusing alternation it has been proposed that the monk behind or beside the couch may be informing the tridaṇḍin of the momentous event or he may, by a use of continuous narration, be Mahākāśyapa, who arrived seven days after the death, learning of it on the road from an ājīvika, the naked and tonsured figure, or, in a sculptural tradition found on Gandhāra reliefs, from another kind of heretical personage instead, the tridaṇḍin. Sometimes a standing monk helps up another; they are identified as Anuruddha and Ānanda. Another figure, variously seated, facing, with back to the viewer or in three-quarter view, and sometimes tonsured, as here, and sometimes with his head covered is identified as Subhadra, the last convert. When this figure has beside him a tripod of three sticks tied to each other to support a suspended bag, explained as a water bag, the reference must be to Subhadra's previous character as a parivrājaka ascetic.

Title: The Dīpaṃkara jātaka. (Object)
Description:
Panel showing the Dīpaṃkara jātaka in three incidents. On the left an oblique doorway with sloping jambs contains a young woman looking up and holding a pot under one arm; the other, with flowers, is raised. She wears a wreath headdress with a projecting loop of hair and a flower, earrings, a collar, bracelets and anklets, a thin sleeved blouse shown by small folds at the shoulders, a garment over the left shoulder and a scarf looping into the girdle of her paridhāna. Above the door is a draped balcony with two women similarly dressed, one with arm raised to throw flowers onto the scene below. Beyond the doorway a large figure of the brāhmaṇa student Megha, in a similar posture to the young woman's, holds a small water pot and raises his right arm to throw flowers towards the Buddha Dīpaṃkara; he wears a girt animal-skin lower garment, an uttarīya over the left shoulder, the brāhmaṇa's sacrificial thread and long hair under a horizontal length of hair looped at one end. The bare torso shows rounded breasts and abdomen, the left knee is flexed and the head is oval with open eyes between the lids. Below, the same figure is shown prostrate, the back, with its flattened planes, arched above the ground, one arm and leg carried onto the lower frame and the hair clearly being spread onto the ground with Megha's left hand; his left arm continues the angular outline of the back. Above and beside the balcony is a radiate aureole showing Megha in low relief, kneeling, his right knee on the ground, hands joined, his hair now fastened into a chignon.
In front of Megha is the damaged Buddha Dīpaṃkara shown as larger than all the other figures, wearing the usual monastic garments with neckline in relief. He raises his large right hand with long fingers in abhaya, his body a gentle curve. Behind him are the half-length figure of a monk observing and an armed figure standing in almost three-quarter view, lower legs crossed, back turned to the viewer. His long hair is secured by a fillet and his curving moustache on the upturned face conveys, with his rounded staring eyes, a fierce expression. He holds his long sword by its pommel, the scabbard is suspended through the bridge at its middle from his right shoulder by a baldrick which continues round the front of the body; a short lower garment is secured by a girdle. The doorway has a sawtooth enrichment on the inner jambs, a cavetto cornice with vertically grooved lotus-petal ornament and a beam protruding at the left.
The frame consists of a sawtooth cornice and at one side a pilaster with a Corinthian capital in two distinct parts, the upper, with central leaf and corners, rather high under an upper capital of two tiers with sawtooth enrichment; on the shaft a garland with narrow ends hangs without visible attachment and under the usual base mouldings seems to be a second plinth. The plain framing fillet at the bottom is grooved as if in continuation of Megha's hair, but see also under the pilaster.
Dimensions: Height: 42.20 centimetres with dowl ; Height: 40.30 centimetres without dowl ; Width: 47.90 centimetres; Depth: 9.50 centimetres
Curators Comments:
Zwalf 1996:
In the frame of the extended story in the Mahāvastu of Dīpaṃkara, Buddha Śākyamuni's predecessor, many details parallel the legend of Śākyamuni, but the king is Arcimat and the city Dīpavatī; the Bodhisattva whose Buddhahood as Śākyamuni Dīpaṃkara predicts is Megha. Megha saw Dīpavatī in festive array and learnt from a brāhmaṇa girl, Prakṛti, that Dīpaṃkara was awaited. From her he obtained, also to honour Dīpaṃkara, five of the flowers she was carrying in a pitcher in return for marriage in future births, a condition without effect on the Bodhisattva vow he made on seeing Dīpaṃkara arriving in procession; both Megha and Prakṛti threw their flowers which remained suspended all around Dīpaṃkara's head, stalks turned inwards, Megha spread his robe on the ground, threw himself at Dīpaṃkara's feet and wiped their soles with his hair as he made his vow. As Dīpaṃkara predicted its fulfilment, Megha rose to the height of a palm tree, threw his cloak over one shoulder and joined his hands in homage. In the Pāli tradition the Bodhisattva, Sumedha of Amaravatī, joined in preparing the road for Dīpaṃkara's visit to the town of Ramma(ka) or Rammavatī and, on seeing Dīpaṃkara, spread his mantle and hair, lay down in the mire like a bridge of planks and resolved to become a Buddha rather than reach only Nirvāṇa. Dīpaṃkara foretold that he should be Śākyamuni and offered him eight handfuls of flowers. The summary account in the Dhammapada Commentary to vv. 11-12 omits any Bodhisattva vow and instead makes the act one of especial courtesy (translated Burlingame, 1921: I, 193-4).
With no sure exceptions [Peshawar 1847 (Ingholt, 1957: fig. 188) may seem to be an exception], representations of this theme use continuous narration and Megha can appear up to four times when he obtains flowers from the girl, throws them, lies prostrate and levitates. His commonest appearances are throwing flowers and lying prostrate, while the transaction with the girl is often implied by her presence as onlooker, usually on the left of the panel and often framed in a doorway; Megha also usually faces Dīpaṃkara from the same direction, and when levitating he may kneel, sometimes in a halo, as in this panel, or is apparently upright, but examples of an almost horizontal flying figure seem confined to Japanese collections. In some instances Megha's hair is clearly spread below Dīpaṃkara's feet, but Foucher distinguishes Dīpaṃkara's treading on it, as in the Divyāvadāna, and Megha's wiping Dīpaṃkara's feet as in the Mahāvastu, which is shown by Megha's hand on Dīpaṃkara's ankle. Dīpaṃkara is accompanied by one or more of his monks (both Mahāvastu 1.231 and Divyāvadāna (c.250) refer to large numbers), but Vajrapāṇi is not invariable.
Megha is the name used for the brāhmaṇa student in the Mahāvastu account; in the Divyāvadāna he is Sumati and in the Pāli account Sumedha. In the completely different frame-story of the Divyāvadāna (Dharmarucyavadāna) c.246-53 the king is Dīpa, the city Dīpavatī and the future Bodhisattva is Sumati. All flowers at Dīpavatī had been requisitioned by Dīpa to honour Dīpaṃkara, but the lotuses in a young woman's pitcher rose up through Sumati's merits and she gave him five, keeping two, in return for the promise of marriage in all future births. When thrown, their flowers formed circular canopies that moved or stood with Dīpaṃkara, and in a muddy place Sumati asked Dīpaṃkara to stand on his ascetic's hair (jaṭā) in token of Sumati's future Buddhahood; when Dīpaṃkara did so and affirmed it, Sumati rose the height of seven fan-palm trees. For a German translation see Zimmer, 1925: 42-60.

Title: The Dīpaṃkara jātaka. (Object)
Description:
Stupa drum panel showing the Dīpaṃkara jātaka in three incidents. On the left a frontal figure of Megha takes flowers from the girl before the oblique doorway, another raises a bunch to throw and a third spreads his hair at Dīpaṃkara's feet. Prakṛti is very indistinct but clearly wears anklets. Beside the doorway is a tree. Beyond Dīpaṃkara a worn Vajrapāṇi with vajra diagonal beside his left shoulder turns towards him.
On the right, three very worn figures, one with hands joined, the other in uttarīya, stand beside a Buddha or monk who faces the viewer, his left hand raised and pendent right hand hidden in the garment.
On the cornice, between fasciae with sawtooth enrichment, simplified grooved horizontal "S" brackets with acanthus capitals spring from framed and horizontal panels with lotus-petal enrichment on their soffit.
Dimensions: Diameter: 8.90 centimetres; Height: 13.40 centimetres; Width: 33 centimetres

Description:
Fragment of a panel showing Vajrapāṇi and other attendant figures.
Vajrapāṇi is naked save for a short loincloth and a lion's skin, the forepaws knotted under the neck. His chin and cheeks are emphatically modelled, his forehead is furrowed, his neck is muscular and he has a moustache. His breasts and navel are indicated, his abdomen swells gently and his legs narrow at the knees. He holds a faceted vajra in his right hand and the pommel of his sword with the thumb and fourth finger of the left hand, the index and middle fingers raised; his stance is flexed, his head turned towards the centre of the panel where the Buddha may be presumed. The sword hangs by a suspension bridge on the scabbard from a baldrick passing round his right hip and a pointed strip hangs from a disc on the baldrick.
To the right are two monks with similar but more gently modelled faces. The lower monk, who is older, has deeper-set eyes and a creased forehead, and on both monks their shaven heads are defined by a hairline. The right arm of each emerges from a robe with dense and regular folds. The younger monk above makes the same finger gesture as Vajrapāṇi. Above Vajrapāṇi a turbaned figure, wearing an uttarīya, a collar and a necklace with multiple strands, an armlet and earrings, may have had joined hands. His turban has bands set with discs and radiating from a faceted central bead, a vertical loop of cloth with a pendent end on the side and a crest with a floral ornament. He shows some asymmetry of feature, a sharp nose, full cheeks and a slightly jutting chin.
The frame is a moulded border and within it a band of scrolling, enclosing four-petalled rosettes.
Dimensions: Height: 61.50 centimetres with mount ; Height: 54 centimetres; Thickness: 12.50 centimetres with mount ; Thickness: 7.50 centimetres; Width: 25 centimetres with mount ; Width: 25 centimetres
Curators Comments:
Blurton, 1997:
This relief was once part of a larger panel which, in all probability, featured a Buddha figure at the centre and the Bodhisattva Padmapāṇi on the opposite side. The Buddha flanked by two Bodhisattvas was a common arrangement in Buddhist sculpture from early in its history. The representation of Vajrapāṇi shows that his iconography, at least in ancient Gandhāra, was in part derived from Hercules (see 1776.1108.2) who often wears a lion-skin in the same manner, recalling the hero's defeat of the Nemean Lion. Hercules was widely venerated as a hero and saviour in western Asia during the early centuries of the present era. As a great champion, who nevertheless understood the human condition, Hercules was easily assimilated into Mahāyāna Buddhism.
This relief, aside from its interest as a document of religious development, illustrates a well-known phenomenon in the history of art, namely, that images change in meaning before they change in appearance.; Zwalf 1996:
The manner of wearing the lion's skin is common in the iconography of Heracles (see Lexicon, 1981-8: iv, 7281F., 79iff.) and it derives from his slaying of the Nemean lion; the same style was adopted by or for rulers claiming descent from Heracles, among whom was Alexander the Great. For the diffusion of Heracles in the East and his influence on the Vajrapani iconography see page 44.

Description: Part of a corner panel showing a worshipper. On the shaft of the return, where the capital and mouldings are continued, is a garland hanging by one end.

Description: Part of a panel showing two worshippers. Description: Fragment of a panel with a standing turbaned Bodhisattva in ahhaya. The uttarīya is in the wide mode and on the left arm lies as on BM 1880.72 but here without trace of drapery held across the body. A twisted girdle at the left side must be the top of the paridhāna. The full face is round to oval with long narrow eyes set apart, a damaged nose, long mouth and full chin. There is no ūrṇā. The turban has two plain bands radiating over a cross-hatched pattern from a large central bead between ring terminals and a large circular crest with radiating pleats and a fall of pleated cloth from a central medallion. At each side, against the plain halo, is a more or less vertical loop of cloth while pleats project below. The hair is barely visible; the earrings are with thick rounded hoops. On the torso there is only a collar with an indistinct pattern of crescents and on the abhaya arm a single bracelet; the damaged hand is webbed and attached to the upper right arm. Beside the head are pendent branches, probably from above and beside the seated Buddha, perhaps preaching in a triad with flanking Bodhisattvas, although on such panels flanking Bodhisattvas of equal height with a tree canopy seem rare.

Description: Fragment of a panel with a standing figure, perhaps a Bodhisattva, as a framing element. The uttarīya is in the narrow mode with an end hanging on the left side and the paridhāna hangs with a pointed edge on the left leg. The torso is slightly modelled and the left knee is thrust forward under the paridhāna. From the top of the figure a plain collar, part of a halo, an indistinct earring and on one arm the remains of a bracelet survive. What may have been a garland or fabric in the left hand loops above it, and at the right shoulder the broken outline beside the vertical border may have been a lotus. If it was held in the right hand which, to judge by the rough surface, was also joined to the upper arm, the stalk may have been party undercut. The left-hand figure flanking the Buddha on Peshawar 427M may be another instance of this iconography. The figure stands between, or is framed by, two vertical walls but only the right wall is doubled by a recessed inner wall and the other has a mainly smooth outer side facing the rest of the panel now lost.

Description: Part of a stupa drum panel showing two ascetics. An old ascetic, bearded and with long hair coiled tightly at the back, his eyes deep-set, carries a water pot in his left hand, the arm draped in an upper garment; his gaunt right arm is raised and the back of the hand appears to touch, or knock at, the side of the framing element. This may be a sculptural convenience. Beside him a younger ascetic, bare to the waist, his head turned and with long hair and a chignon set forward and strands looped round the back, carries a pot in his raised left hand while the long expressive fingers of the right hand with its wristlet seem to indicate the blind old man, perhaps mockingly. The pot is broken below its narrow neck. The worn framing element contains a woman, presumably a yakṣī, with a scarf falling from her shoulders. She stands on the pot base of a Persepolitan column which resumes above her with the bell element, the hemispheres with lotus-petal enrichment separated by cable moulding and addorsed bulls under a bracket. At the bottom of the panel are vestiges  of a  framing fillet.
Dimensions: Diameter: 5.50 centimetres; Height: 30.50 centimetres; Width: 30.20 centimetres

Description:
Panel showing the seated and emaciated Bodhisattva flanked by gods and worshippers. 
The Bodhisattva's damaged forearms originally met in dhyāna; he is naked to the waist where a twisted roll of textile forms a girdle; the upper garment is distinguishable only as a narrow strip wound above each elbow and falling to the side. Below the waist he is covered with very summary indications of a garment, but the soles seem bare. His head, unevenly sliced at right angles to the slab, is bearded on one side along the jaw to the chin and still has one deep-set eye, a prominent cheek-bone and horizontal mouth below a moustache. The hair is drawn back from a sharp hairline into the uṣṇīṣa. The very large halo, but for an inner groove defining a border, is plain. The flat-shouldered torso is ribbed, the top of the rib cage plunging in a deep 'V' below the protruding vertebrae. Nippled breasts project slightly and the waist is indrawn at the navel. The posture is dramatically straight and still, the arms bony. The face of the grass-covered rectangular seat has triangular panels each containing a large, roughly triangular indentation.
To his right stands a bearded, hirsute and lean-faced Vajrapāṇi who holds below his right shoulder a vajra that is almost a long baton; he has both shoulders covered by a long garment and at the broad flat girdle he is in very low relief. In higher relief beside him is a full-faced woman wearing a long tunic falling about her feet and a long overgarment draped over her left shoulder, her sleeves of thick material, her joined hands containing perhaps a floral offering or garland. She wears hoop earrings, a collar and hair coiled at the back of the head and resembling a wreath. Opposite, a standing male figure, corresponding to Vajrapāṇi but turning sideways, wears Indra's headdress with a moulded cylindrical top, earrings, collar and uttarīya; he holds flowers in both hands. Beside him a male figure wearing a sleeved tunic and an uttarīya, earrings and collar, joins his hands with an offering also.
Below are a plain framing fillet and an uneven groove suggesting a plinth at the base of the seat.
Dimensions: Diameter: 6.80 centimetres; Height: 18.30 inches; Width: 19.80 centimetres
Curators Comments:
Descriptions of the Bodhisattva's fruitless search for enlightenment by traditional austerities, which reduced him to extreme emaciation, are described in some detail in the texts naming the forms of practice which induced it and it has recently been argued that the yogic concepts of the cakras, and the brahmarandhra in particular, may explain the concentration, in apparently significant numbers, of holes in the uṣṇīṣa of the fasting Bodhisattva in Gandhara. During these practices gods reported his imminent death to the Bodhisattva's mother in the Trāyastriṃśa heaven, but when she came she was consoled that he would attain nirvāṇa; she left him to continue his practices but his father sent daily messengers to learn of his son's condition and the gods watched day and night and worshipped him. Now the Bodhisattva decided that asceticism did not lead to salvation and resolved to take food again. The gods offered to feed him through the pores of his hair but he refused and preferred either to prepare his own food, supplemented with milk-rice from Sujātā, a village headman's daughter, or to take it from her entirely. The Pāli tradition is, in canonical accounts, substantially similar as to the ascetic practices, but the story of Sujātā and her food offering to the Bodhisattva as he sat under a 'nyagrodha' is in the commentatorial literature and refers to the eve of the Enlightenment when the Bodhisattva had already begged food, broken his fast and resumed his former appearance.
Apparently evolved in and at first confined to Gandhāra, figures of the fasting Bodhisattva, whether large, as at Lahore and Peshawar, or that from Shotorak and smaller pieces, may have been meditational images besides serving narrative purposes, perhaps with separate flanking figures. Relief panels with flanking figures are not especially numerous and also differ among themselves too much to provide dependable explanations for this piece. Examples with female assistants are inconclusive and male assistants range from donors to deities.
For quite exceptional sequences of very unusual aspect see Berlin MIK 1 79,14 where, from right to left, the emaciated Bodhisattva is flanked by Brahmā and Indra and crosses the Nairañjanā and, quite restored, receives bowls from flanking females; and a strip, in a private Japanese collection, where the skeletal Bodhisattva is flanked by tormenting village children, then by women offering a bowl and water pot respectively and, finally, in his normal appearance, receives a bundle of grass.
While it seems certain that the Bodhisattva is here attended by Vajrapāṇi and Indra, the flanking and formally paired male and female worshippers seem like donors and may be intentionally ambiguous. Foucher prefers to see in the outer male worshipper Brahmā with a collar (see BM 1917.0501.1) beside Indra, while the corresponding female, if not Māyā come from the Trāyastriṃśa heaven, then Sujātā offering food.
For a Western affinity for the fasting Bodhisattva seen by Rowland in the brutal realism of the Hellenistic art of Alexandria, compare Lamb, 1929: pl. LXXVIIa.; Zwalf 1985
Disappointed by spiritual masters, the Bodhisattva took to severe fasting and was even reported dead. When fasts failed to reveal the truth, he turned to the middle way between worldliness and mortification, one definition of the Buddhist path to salvation. He accepted a rice-brew from a village headman's daughter, who had come to offer it to a nature spirit in thanksgiving for the birth of a son. She stands beside the emaciated Bodhisattva with his frequent companions, the gods Indra and Brahmā, and his protector Vajrapāṇi.
Bib references: Zwalf 1985 / Buddhism: Art and Faith; Zwalf 1996 / A Catalogue of the Gandhara Sculpture in the British Museum

Description:
Part of a panel with an undulating garland and amorini. From right to left the figures are: in the dip of the garland a damaged half-length male with his right hand before his chest apparently turning his damaged head towards the first amorino; an amorino seen from the back and striding to the right, glancing backwards over his shoulder, with one arm under the garland and the other placed on it; in the dip a half-length figure, holding a bowl, looking towards the amorino on his right; an amorino turning to his right with one arm passing under the garland, the other by his side. The amorini are plump, one showing genitals, and with rounded and protruding eyes. The garland is in four sections, two of leaf pattern, one of twisted beaded and undulating bands between plain bands and one of rounded petals with a small central indentation. The sections are separated by ribbons, in one case knotted on the underside of the garland and falling to the ground. At the bottom of the dips are (left) three lotus buds and (right) blown flowers and a bud hanging by their stalks. 
The framing fillet above is damaged; the prominent mouldings of the plinth are a torus and a somewhat angular cavetto under a fillet.
Dimensions: Diameter: 8.70 centimetres; Height: 13.50 centimetres; Width: 26 centimetres
Curators Comments:
Zwalf 1996:
The garland running around the stupa may be seen as an offering with fertility imagery where the amorino is appropriately a yakṣa. The earlier garlanding of domes is illustrated at Bharhut and Sanci, where, as perhaps at Chatpat and Taxila, it was supported by pegs (compare BM 1892.1103.78, BM 1959.0717.1, BM 1949.0718.48 and BM 1904.1217.32).
The stone garland frieze, frequent on single narrow panels, both flat and curved, is not often found on the same slab as other horizontal registers. It occurs under a false gable arch, on stupa domes, on solid drums, on a fragment showing a double-domed roof, on a rectangular stupa platform, as an integral register below a preaching Buddha panel and below a row of Buddhas. The motif is found on stair-risers (BM 1880.883 and BM 1880.59) and on a panel reused beside the porch of a shrine at Butkara III.
The classical affinities of the continuous garland are referred generally to the eastern Mediterranean and a 2nd-century introduction. Combaz, with comparisons, proposes the garland frieze in Gandhāra as a classicising expression of a vegetal motif already present in the Indian tradition. The diffusion of the garland from Gandhāra may be seen at Kuṣāṇa Mathurā and, in the fifth century, in Kashmir.
For reliefs showing garlands on stupa domes, without amorini and perhaps to be thought of as hanging from pegs like BM 1892.1103.78, BM 1959.0717.1 and BM 1949.0718.48; see also BM 1902.1002.29 (with open flowers in the dips as at Butkara I).
 For a frequent but different treatment of the single festoon see BM 1900.0414.5.
Bib references: Zwalf 1996 / A Catalogue of the Gandhara Sculpture in the British Museum

Description:
Panel, perhaps a stair-riser, showing six standing watermen, perhaps marine or river spirits. All six stand in somewhat varied postures but all, save one, who is leaning on it, carry a paddle over the left shoulder. They have moustaches and short projecting beards, finely grooved linear hair parted in the middle with V-shaped locks above the forehead and longer locks behind, pointed ears where they clear the hair; the eyes are open and ringed with narrow lids, the faces long and modelled to show cheekbones, sharp noses and lips. The chests are broad beneath ridges for collar-bones, except on one figure, and on all but that figure musculature is clumsily modelled below the breast as small mounds in two rows of four. Below the abdomen hang skirts like acanthus leaves and the short boots have rolled tops. The legs, with swelling musculature above and below the knees, are carved in a variety of postures, some partly undercut or in high relief. Two, if not three, alternating figures hold up the right hand with the index and little fingers raised and the two middle fingers held down by the thumb; and the second figure from the right holds a dolphin seen frontally. Marshall, 1960: 37, referring to this piece, calls this 'the gesture of Good Luck'.
On the right is a Corinthian column framed except at the top, the capital in distinct upper and lower parts with volutes overlapping the inner frame and the base with Attic mouldings, the scotia appearing more as a groove. A vertical mason's line to the right marks the edge of the frame proper and another, horizontal, marks the division of the two parts of the capital; the rest of the panel on that side remains blocked out. The plinth is moulded with a torus and fillet.
Dimensions: Diameter: 4.80 centimetres; Height: 16.50 centimetres without tenons ; Width: 43.20 centimetres
Curators Comments:
Zwalf 1996:
This panel is thought to be a riser from a set generally, but on no good evidence, attributed to Buner II). The subject has, since Foucher, generally been taken to be marine or river deities, but a set of boatmen or other donors honouring the Buddha have also been suggested.

Title: Saṃcodana (Object); Śvetaketu in the Tuṣita Heaven (Object)
Description:
Panel showing a turbaned Bodhisattva in dhyāna and two kneeling figures, perhaps Siddhārtha with Brahmā and Indra. The haloed Bodhisattva wears an uttarīya over both shoulders; one end passes under his right arm while the other lies over the left elbow, leaving the chest bare. A pleated end of the paridhāna falls onto the rectangular seat between the knees. On the turban bands meet at a large central bead beneath a fantail crest with pointed conical ornament and a summarily executed vertical loop of cloth with an end below projects at both sides. The Bodhisattva wears a collar and necklace, both plain, earrings and bracelets. His head is oval and regular, the face slightly fleshy with protruding rounded eyes, the edges above them for eyebrows and the curved mouth sharp. The torso is broad and spreading with raised breasts beside the necklace and a globular navel. Above him branches with large, more or less paired leaves curve upwards.
On the Bodhisattva's left a turbaned kneeling figure wears uttarīya and paridhāna and joins his hands as if to leave a space between them. He may be Indra. His turban and ornaments are like those of the Bodhisattva. Opposite a figure kneels similarly and in similar dress, but with collar only and long hair beneath a horizontal length of hair, knotted in the middle and looped at one end; the joined hands are damaged. The face, with protruding rounded eyes like those on the other figures, is fuller and fleshier and if the figure is Brahmā the collar is exceptional.
Behind both flanking figures and along the edge of the panel are tree trunks in very low relief ending in branches like those above the central figure but straighter. Along the top of the panel is a sawtooth cornice and, projecting on each side, a similarly decorated bracket arm presupposing flanking pilasters. At the bottom are plain fillets.
Dimensions: Diameter: 7.10 centimetres; Height: 22.50 centimetres; Width: 24.10 centimetres
Curators Comments:
Zwalf 1996:
If the presence of Brahmā, notwithstanding the rare collar, is admitted together with that of Indra, this scene may illustrate the Instigation (saṃcodana) in which these and other gods urge the Bodhisattva to renounce the world (see also BM 1890.1116.1). Commenting on the rather loose iconography for this subject, Foucher, 1905-51: 11, 222, refers to instances showing a turbaned and meditating figure under branches which he explains as contamination from outdoor scenes. If instead this scene illustrates the Bodhisattva Śvetaketu in the Tuṣita heaven considering his last birth as Siddhārtha, it has some agreements with the well-known relief from Sikri ascribed to this theme, and there is literary support for the presence of Brahmā and Indra. Lobo, proposing another iconograhy for the Tuṣita scenes, has identified the Sikri panel as showing the Bodhisatva's meditations before the earthly Instigation, and in another, where a turbaned Bodhisattva in dhyāna is shown as here together with Brahmā and Indra, she believes the meditations are combined with the Instigation itself.
For the Instigation the texts relate how, either before or after his revulsion among the women, Indra, Brahmā and other gods urge the Bodhisattva to leave the palace and promise him an unhindered departure and Enlightenment.
Bib references: Zwalf 1996 / A Catalogue of the Gandhara Sculpture in the British Museum

Title: The Dīpaṃkara jātaka. (Object)
Description:
Stupa drum panel showing two scenes, one of the Dīpaṃkara jātaka in two incidents, beneath two horizontal registers. From right to left, in the first scene, the haloed and damaged Dīpaṃkara is in abhaya and three-quarter view. The standing Megha raises his damaged right hand holding flowers, his left holds a broken water pot at his waist; he wears an ascetic's tunic with bared right shoulder and his hair is gathered into a chignon. Megha reappears below in a curved posture on hands and knees, hair perhaps extending below Dlpamkara's feet. An oblique doorway behind, with moulded sloping jambs, a rectangular threshold and an indistinct lintel, frame Prakṛti who holds a pot at her waist. Behind Dīpaṃkara a burly Vajrapāṇi with tightly curled hair holds his vajra along the line of his narrow plunging uttarīya, which just reveals the genitals. Behind him are two monks in rhythmically curved stance, their right arms in the robe across the chest and the left hanging down with a curved gathering of drapery to the bottom of the garment.
In the next scene, in the centre, a turbaned and haloed figure with uttarīya and paridhāna, and showing a muscular chest and arm, stands with one arm down, the other on the hip, wearing the usual ornaments. Beside him his queen is seated on a long draped seat, her raised right hand holding a lotus; she wears a wreath headdress with protruding loop of hair and ornaments. The kneeling figure on each side appears to be female, with anklets and girdles, and hands joined. Behind and beside each suppliant a pair of similar standing females join hands and hold flowers. All the female figures on this panel appear to wear a tunic with a paridhāna round it; features, where they survive, are sharp with rounded eyes.
Flanking the scenes are framed columns with faceted (incomplete) tapering shafts under Corinthian capitals and with tori at the bases recalling pots. Above are an ovolo with pointed leaf enrichment under a fillet and a chequerboard register of alternating blocks and recesses. At the top a register of arches on very summary Corinthian capitals of tapering pilasters, perhaps representing horizontal "S" brackets, contains a series of cult objects, some on rectangular draped bases. From right to left these are: a damaged disc; the Bodhisattva's crested turban; another disc (perhaps the sun disc or halo); an ascetic's hut or a small vihdra with domed roof; the Buddha's begging bowl; another turban; a draped urn; the vajra; another bowl; and a draped urn as more commonly known from the sequence of the Buddha's obsequies.
Dimensions: Diameter: 6.20 centimetres; Height: 22 centimetres; Width: 53.40 centimetres
Curators Comments:
Zwalf 1996:
The subject of this scene is uncertain. It is perhaps a life-scene rather than a jātaka; the haloed figure may be Śuddhodana and the suppliants pleading to be allowed to care for the infant Bodhisattva.
Bib references: Zwalf 1996 / A Catalogue of the Gandhara Sculpture in the British Museum

Title: King Śibi ransoming a pigeon with his own flesh. (Object)
Description:
Panel showing the Bodhisattva as King Śibi ransoming a pigeon with his own flesh. From right to left a youthful haloed deity with moustache and a chignon bound at the base stands almost in profile with his right hand raised, palm outward. He wears a paridhāna and uttarīya, a collar with small pendants and double bracelets, that on his left wrist beaded and with discs. Beside him Indra, slightly turned towards the king, raises his right hand at right angles to himself, the thumb across the palm, a flat vajra in the left hand and wearing paridhāna and uttarīya in the narrow mode. He is crowned with his cylindrical cap, its side cross-hatched and with mouldings above, which rests on a wreath or a rounded ornamental brim, and wears one wide flat bracelet and another like that of the deity beside him, a collar and a necklace. Between him and the group around Śibi an almost frontal figure, turned slightly towards the king and with a small double-looped chignon on a bowl crop hairstyle, earrings, moustache, paridhāna and uttarīya, holds a weighing device of steelyard type consisting of a suspended bar also supported by a damaged hand. At one end what must be the king's flesh is heaped in a suspended bag, its weight measured along the other, longer side of the bar. Above is a damaged projection discussed below.
At the left the drooping king is seated on a throne, supporting himself over one side at the right armpit while with his other arm he clasps the woman in front of him, his hand on her back. The footstool, adorned with three open flowers, emphasises a large foot and the bared leg, thrust forward, from which a kneeling figure with moustache, paridhāna, uttarīya and earrings, cuts with a knife. The king has a moustache, wears a crested turban, a collar with large circular pendants and a necklace, armlets, bracelets, earrings, paridhāna and uttarīya. The woman in front of him, with wreath headdress and necklace, long-sleeved garment, a scarf or long garment draped over her left shoulder and braid on the back, leans forward, stretching out her left hand to the king's side. Above the king is a parasol decorated with a trellised motif; the throne, with back and sides, has a textile draped over the side beneath the king's arm, a floral panel and an elaborate turned leg beside which stands the pigeon.
On all the figures drapery folds are shown by dense grooves and ridges, heads are well shaped, round to oval and the features clear-cut with open eyes and distinct upper lids. The torsos are generally smooth with gentle modelling, nipples and gashed navels on the males. The heavy lids give a certain uniformity of appearance and this suggests a sad and solemn participation of all the protagonists. The king's forehead is puckered in pain and the angle of his head, like that of the other actors, and the forward posture of the woman, whose supporting arm is undercut, emphasise the pathos of the event. The composition balances the group of tall deities observing, Indra now in his true form at the climax of the sacrifice, the central figure of the weigher in a gentle compassionate dehanchement, holding the suspended flesh in emphatic relief, and the heads of the king, the woman and the wiclder of the knife aligned in a triangular scheme.
The broken projection above the figure with the steelyard must be the hawk or falcon; we appear to have continuous narration, with Indra and his earlier form as bird and correspondingly the youthful figure on the right may be the divine Viśvakarmā along with his form as the pigeon.
Dimensions: Diameter: 5.50 centimetres; Height: 23.30 centimetres; Width: 32.40 centimetres
Curators Comments:
Zwalf 1996:
The theme, to be distinguished from Śibi's gift of his eyes (also commemorated on one of the 'four great stupas'), occurs, with variants, in different texts and tells how Indra tested the resolve of the Bodhisattva in his birth as King Śibi. Śibi, who had vowed to protect all creatures, ransomed a pigeon pursued by Indra disguised as a falcon, eagle, or sparrow-hawk, while the pigeon was really the god Viśvakarmā acting at Indra's behest. Śibi offered in his own flesh the equivalent of the pigeon's weight; parts of his body were successively cut off and heaped into a scale, but the pigeon proved still too heavy until the king, with what was left of himself, got into it. In this extremity he reaffirmed his joy at fulfilling the Bodhisattva vow and prayed, in token of his sincerity, to become whole again; and this then came about. The two gods resumed their own forms.
The execution recalls the so-called Buner group; the drapery the 'drawing' manner of Butkara I; Viśvakarmā/Brahmā's necklace that of a spectator on Peshawar 2071 (Ingholt, 1957: fig. 16); and compare Fabregues.
There is no other certain example of this subject in Gandhāra.
Bib references: Zwalf 1996 / A Catalogue of the Gandhara Sculpture in the British Museum; Pemberton 2002 / The Buddha; Errington 2017a / Charles Masson and the Buddhist Sites of Afghanistan: Explorations, Excavations, Collections 1832-1835

Description: Plaque (Buddha). Buddha seated below double trees and meditating; 2 lions in attendance. Earthenware with black patination.
Dimensions: Height: 18 centimetres
Curators Comments:
Zwalf 1985
As with sandalwood objects, few brittle earthenware shrines of the Tang and pre-Tang period survive. It is therefore notable that several are taken either from the same or similar moulds. These depict the Buddha seated below the double trees associated with his death. In China the ‘Mahāpari-nirvāṇasūtra’ was regarded by Zhiyi (AD 531-97), founder of the Tiantai sect, as belonging to the last, supreme stage of the Buddha's teaching, and as Tiantai gained in popularity during the 6th century so did scenes and motifs related to the ‘sūtra’. In this case Sakyamuni is shown meditating below the trees, not lying.
Bib references: Zwalf 1985 / Buddhism: Art and Faith
Assoc events: Associated Event: Death of Buddha

The fragmentary head is surrounded by a halo and has strongly elongated earlobes. The figure was made of yellowish clay using a mould and was covered with a white slip before being fired.

Description: Fragment of relief plaque made of brown unfired clay. Shown is a Buddha seated cross-legged, with his hands held in what is probably the vajra mudrā (literally "thunder mudrā"). This gesture, made by extending the index finger of one hand upward and the other hand making a fist and enclosing it, is the gesture of knowledge. The Buddha wears a robe with prominent folds and is seated in front of a mandorla, his head surrounded by a nimbus. The whole figure is surrounded by a circle of lotus leaves.

Description: Fragment of clay relief plaque showing a seated Buddha. He has a head nimbus enclosed by a plain band and is shown seated against a  vesica bordered by lotus petals. His legs are crossed, the eyes closed, the hands held in the meditation position (dhyāna mudrā). The plaque was made using a mould and fired. Traces of paint are still visible.
Find spot: Excavated/Findspot: Siyelik;  Excavated/Findspot: 斯耶里克 (Chinese)
Technique: mould-made; painted; 模製 (Chinese); 烘乾的 (Chinese)
Dimensions: Height: 9.50 centimetres; Width: 7.50 centimetres
Curators Comments:
Zwalf 1985
Miniature Buddha images were affixed to the haloes surrounding larger figures, while their small size also made them ideal for the devotions of individual worshippers. They were made of clay in one-piece moulds (see no. 278). The lotus petals form a surround to the Buddha, seated with legs crossed at the ankles, and hands laid in the lap. In the earliest Chinese images from the cave temples at Dunhuang larger figures with crossed ankles represent Maitreya, the Buddha of the Future.

Acq notes (acq): The 1917-11-28 group (with MAS numbering) refers to objects from Stein's  Second Central Asian Expedition, 1906-08. As the expedition was financed 3/ 5 by the Government of India and 2/5 by the British Museum, it was agreed  that the finds from the expedition should be allocated in these proportions. All  the finds were shipped to London for sorting, research and publication, and  subsequent distribution. The distribution of the finds between London and  India was determined by specialists, appointed by the Government of India  (through the India Office, London) and the British Museum, who drew up  lists of the objects for approval by both sides. The specialists included:  Raphael Petrucci, under supervision of Dr E Denison Ross (nominated by  India Office) and Laurence Binyon (British Museum) on paintings;  Dr F W  Thomas, Dr E Denison Ross (both nominated by India Office) and Dr L D  Barnett (British Museum) on manuscripts and written documents; Dr E  Denison Ross (nominated by India Office) and Laurence Binyon (British  Museum) on archaeological/other finds. Although the lists were drawn up and  approved in 1915, the Government of India asked the British Museum to look  after the entire collection during the First World War, and those allocated to  India were eventually shipped in 1919.

Description: Fragment of a clay relief plaque showing a seated Buddha. He is shown seated in meditation pose, with his legs crossed and the hands held in the dhyāna mudrā (gesture of meditation) in his lap. His ears are strongly elongated and the head surrounded by a nimbus. The plaque was made using a mould, covered with a red slip and then fired. It is  in good condition, except for the face which has chipped off.
Technique: mould-made; slipped; 烘乾的 (Chinese); 模製 (Chinese)
Dimensions: Height: 16.80 centimetres; Width: 13.10 centimetres
Curators Comments:
English
From Whitfield 1985:
This seated figure, entirely flat at the back, was made in a mould as an appliqué piece. It was one of the Buddha figures in the nimbus of a colossal standing figure of the Buddha, of which only the lower legs and drapery were still extant when Stein examined and photographed the site (see Ancient Khotan, Pl. XIVb). The oval head, which has lost the facial features, echoes the treatment seen in the large head (Pl. 63). The regular drapery folds are for the most part simple incised lines, hugging the form beneath and following the general conventions of Gandharan sculpture. Due to early consolidation work, the surface of the figure has acquired a shine which differs from the matt appearance of the original red clay wash.; Chinese
From Whitfield 1985:
此佛坐像的背面完全是平的，是用模子製作的化佛。化佛是安裝在巨大佛立像的頭光上的，當斯坦因考查此遺迹進行拍照時，那巨像的腳尖和衣紋還殘留著（參照《古代和田》圖版XIV.b）。頭部爲橢圓形，面部已經破損，其色彩大概與圖63的佛頭相同。另外，衣紋線基本是用簡單而有規則的刻線表現，衣服下的線條很有肉感，大概融合了犍陀羅雕刻的流派。由於早期的固化作用，像的表面出現一層光澤，這與紅粘土製品表面沒有光澤是不同的。

Description: Fragment of clay relief plaque. Shown is a  Buddha seated cross-legged, with his hands held in what is probably  the vajra mudrā (literally "thunder mudrā"). This gesture, made by extending the index finger of one hand upward and the other hand  making a fist and enclosing it, is the gesture of knowledge. The  Buddha wears a robe with prominent folds and is seated in front of a  mandorla, his head surrounded by a nimbus. The whole figure is  surrounded by a circle of lotus leaves The plaque was made using a mould and then covered with a red slip.
Technique: mould-made; 烘乾的 (Chinese); 模製 (Chinese); slipped
Dimensions: Diameter: 8.80 centimetres
Curators Comments:
English
From Whitfield 1985:
Miniature plaques such as these were produced in quantity by the use of moulds, and applied to form parts of the nimbus decoration of larger statues. In the case of many of the Rawak figures, this decoration was quite elaborate (see Gropp, 1974, Fig. 110, p. 233), and they appear around the edges of the aureoles of standing figures as well as in the nimbus (see Ancient Khotan, Pl. XVIIIc). As Stein himself wrote:
Special artistic interest attaches to the remains of the elaborate aureoles which ... encircled these statues. They varied but little in details. Every-where there was a border formed by a cloud-scroll, and within it a broad band showing small plaques of seated Buddhas or Bodhisattvas inserted between wreaths of a very graceful bead-ornament. The latter were gathered at intervals into bunches surmounted y a fleur-de-lis. A second band of small seated Buddhas seems to have filled the space left between the highly ornamental border and the edges of the drapery. (Ibid., Vol. I, p.499)
The plaque from Dandan-oilik, probably somewhat later than that from Rawak, had a similar purpose: it bears traces of pigment as follows: “hair black, robe brown, seat pink, inner part of vesica pink, outer ray emerald green. The whole appears to have been on background of indigo” (ibid., Vol. I, p.289).; Chinese
From Whitfield 1985:
像这樣的小裝飾是使用模子大量製作的，一部分是用於大型佛像的背光上。熱瓦克的諸像中，有很多非常精巧的這種裝飾（參照Gropp，1974，Fig. 110，233頁），不僅在頭光上，立像身光的周邊也使用（參照《古代和田》圖版XVIII.c）。斯坦因对此有如下叙述：
“從環繞這些像的漂亮背光的斷片上感到了特殊的美。它們的細部表現上只有小的差異，其邊緣都有火焰，內側非常美的連珠圓紋中，是貼著佛或菩薩坐像小裝飾板的寬的帶狀部分。連珠紋的連接處有百合花狀的裝飾。小坐佛的第二列，是極具裝飾性的邊緣部分，大概是爲了填充衣紋端部的空間配了裝飾”（參照《古代和田》卷一，499頁）。
丹丹烏里克的作品大概比熱瓦克的年代還晚些，但用途相同。有關其色彩，斯坦因有如下記述：“頭髮是黑色，衣服爲茶褐色，台座是淺紅色，背光的裏面爲淡紅，外面的部分是淡綠色。全用青色做背景。”（參照《古代和田》卷一，289頁）

Relief plaque made of a very light-coloured stucco that was moulded and painted. It is a representation of the Buddha in  meditation pose seated on a small lotus throne and against a double mandorla. The plaque was painted in green, red, white and black but only traces of pigments remain.

Curators Comments:
English
From Whitfield 1985:
Miniature plaques such as these were produced in quantity by the use of moulds, and applied to form parts of the nimbus decoration of larger statues. In the case of many of the Rawak figures, this decoration was quite elaborate (see Gropp, 1974, Fig. 110, p. 233), and they appear around the edges of the aureoles of standing figures as well as in the nimbus (see Ancient Khotan, Pl. XVIIIc). As Stein himself wrote:
Special artistic interest attaches to the remains of the elaborate aureoles which ... encircled these statues. They varied but little in details. Every-where there was a border formed by a cloud-scroll, and within it a broad band showing small plaques of seated Buddhas or Bodhisattvas inserted between wreaths of a very graceful bead-ornament. The latter were gathered at intervals into bunches surmounted y a fleur-de-lis. A second band of small seated Buddhas seems to have filled the space left between the highly ornamental border and the edges of the drapery. (Ibid., Vol. I, p.499)
The plaque from Dandan-oilik, probably somewhat later than that from Rawak, had a similar purpose: it bears traces of pigment as follows: “hair black, robe brown, seat pink, inner part of vesica pink, outer ray emerald green. The whole appears to have been on background of indigo” (ibid., Vol. I, p.289).; Chinese
From Whitfield 1985:
像这樣的小裝飾是使用模子大量製作的，一部分是用於大型佛像的背光上。熱瓦克的諸像中，有很多非常精巧的這種裝飾（參照Gropp，1974，Fig. 110，233頁），不僅在頭光上，立像身光的周邊也使用（參照《古代和田》圖版XVIII.c）。斯坦因对此有如下叙述：
“從環繞這些像的漂亮背光的斷片上感到了特殊的美。它們的細部表現上只有小的差異，其邊緣都有火焰，內側非常美的連珠圓紋中，是貼著佛或菩薩坐像小裝飾板的寬的帶狀部分。連珠紋的連接處有百合花狀的裝飾。小坐佛的第二列，是極具裝飾性的邊緣部分，大概是爲了填充衣紋端部的空間配了裝飾”（參照《古代和田》卷一，499頁）。

Description: Plate, earthenware (' pearl ware', decorated with the  'brown water lily' pattern, transfer-printed in black and painted in brown and orange and gilt with botanical subjects; rim gilt. Marked.
Dimensions: Diameter: 9.80 inches
Inscription: Inscription type: maker's mark Inscription position: reverse Inscription quoted: WEDGWOOD Inscription note: impressed
Curators Comments:
Dawson 1984
Amongst the most remarkable of all services made during this period is the well-known pearlware 'Water Lily' service ordered in 1807 and delivered in 1808 to Dr Robert Darwin, son of Dr Erasmus Darwin and father of the evolutionist Charles Darwin. This plate is from the service and was given to A. W. Franks by Dr Joseph Hooker (1817-1911), Director of Kew Gardens between 1865 and 1885 and friend of Charles Darwin. The 'Water Lily' pattern almost certainly represents the earliest use of brown underglaze printing in Staffordshire that can be accurately dated. The decision to introduce the manufacture of underglaze printed ware at Etruria (overglaze printing having been used since the 1770s) was taken on 31 March 1805. The 'Water Lily' pattern was the first to be used at Etruria that reproduced identifiable botanical prints. The engravings of the water lilies, all members of the 'Nymphaeaceae' family, indigenous to watery places, have been identified as: 'nymphaea stellata', or starry water lily, on the left; 'nymphaea lotus', or Lotus of Egypt, on the right; and 'nelumbium speciosum', or sacred Lotus of Buddha, the fully opened flower in the centre, with large, veined indented leaves. The lilies were all copied either from the 'Botanist's Repository' or from the 'Botanical Magazine', periodicals published, between October 1803 and February 1806.
See Una des Fontaines, 'The Darwin Service and the first printed patterns at Eturia', Proc Wedg Soc, Vol. II, no. 6, 1966, pp. 69-90

Description:
A two-sided slab carved in limestone: 
1. Back (Knox 1992: cat. no.3): fragment of a fluted railing pillar (recut to make the drum slab on the reverse face) adorned with a half-lotus, a row of sea monsters (makaras), a garuda and naga, purnaghatas and a floral border. On the flat area below the sea monsters is a group of lightly engraved lotuses with heads hanging down.
2. Front (Knox 1992: cat. no.74):  The drum-slab on the reverse face of this slab (originally part of an abandoned railing pillar) depicts a five headed naga in the gateway with narrative reliefs on the drum frieze and the dome. On the drum frieze are the First Sermon and The Enlightenment; on the ayaka panel the Elevation of the Head-dress flanked by the First Sermon and the Enlightenment, the  Worship of a Pillar and the First Sermon; on the dome is the Birth of the Buddha, the Interpretation of the Dream, the Dream of Queen Maya, the Descent of the Buddha and a palace scene, possibly the Buddha in the Tusita heaven.

Title: railing pillar (Object)
Description: Railing pillar carved in limestone ('Palnad marble') with lotus medallions and narrative reliefs. The outer face is lost, but the inner face depicts one half-lotus and a narrative in the central lotus roundel; probably the infant Siddhartha (represented symbolically) nursed by the old man Asita. The lower fluted area depicts the visit of Asita and his nephew Naradatta.
Dimensions: Height: 200 centimetres; Width: 84.10 centimetres
Curators Comments:
Blurton, 1997:
The great Buddhist stūpa at Amarāvatī was one of the most important centres of Buddhism in southern India from the early centuries of the present era until its complete abandonment some time after the fourteenth century. This pre-eminence was initially based on the economic power of the Sātavāhana kings who are closely associated with the city of Dharaṇīkoṭa, close to the stūpa. During the Sātavāhana period, the city no doubt provided a ready source of patronage, a situation only changed by the rise of the Ikṣvāku dynasty based at Nāgārjunakoṇḍa further up the river Krishna.
In the manner of early Buddhist stūpa, the whole structure was surrounded by a railing fence of which the present example is a part. The railing, vedikā, was made up of upright elements (such as this) and cross-bars which connected these standing, horizontal parts. The outer faces of the uprights were decorated with lotus blossoms and small figural scenes -including those showing gaṇas playing music and dancing. The inner face, as seen here, was the face which would have been seen by devotees performing pradakṣiṇā; this was conceived rather differently. Here scenes from the life of the Buddha and from the jātakas were shown, as moral precepts to be 'read' by those who processed around the stūpa.
Of great interest in the roundel is the symbolic indication of the presence of the holy child, by footprints on the cloth held by the old man in the centre of the roundel. There is no bodily image shown. This relief belongs to that earlier period at Amaravati when the bodily form is still only shown symbolically; during the next century this was to change with profound consequences not only in the Indian subcontinent, but throughout Southeast Asia and the Far East.

Description:
Reilquary casket (replica); made in a copper alloy; inscribed.
A replica of the so-called Kanishka reliquary, electroformed. On the lid is a seated Buddha flanked by figures of Brahmā and Indra; the sides of the casket carry a running garland support by puti and a standing king in central Asian dress.
Find spot: Found/Acquired: London (England) (source of the replica reliquary)
Dimensions: Diameter: 10.50 centimetres; Height: 19.20 centimetres
Inscription: Inscription type: inscription Inscription position: on the lid and outside body of the piece Inscription script: Kharoshthi Inscription note: The inscription is a dedication to the Sarvastivadin Buddhist sect.
Curators Comments:
Zwalf 1985
This reliquary, excavated from the presumed site of the famous 'stūpa' of Kaniṣka I, is generally supposed, also on the basis of the incomplete inscription, to be a deposit by that king, but the inscription, a dedication to the Sarvāstivādin sect, contains no date in Kaniṣka's era, as was once thought. The lid has haloed figures of the Buddha, Brahmā (right) and Indra (left); on the box are a standing personage in Kuṣāṇa dress, who has been taken for a beardless Kaniṣka, flanked by the personified sun and moon, and meditating Buddhas worshipped by haloed figures, perhaps Brahmā and Indra. Although the Buddha image appears of an early type and the style of the casket has been much discussed, its manufacture in Gandhara seems certain.
Bib references: Zwalf 1985 / Buddhism: Art and Faith

One copy was kept in the BM (1880.270) as a reward for the work and the original and the second replica returned to Peshawar (NWFP, Pakistan) where they are to this day in the Museum there.

Title: The Wardak Vase (Object)
Description: Globular reliquary vase of copper alloy, with a narrow neck and everted rim. The vase has a low, flat ring-foot, a band of three grooves around the middle, two at the base of the neck, two inside the neck just below the rim and another on the everted and sloping rim. An inscription in Kharoshthi in four lines is dated in the Kushan year 51 in the reign of the Kushan king Huvishka (c. 150-191).
Dimensions: Diameter: 16.90 centimetres; Diameter: 9.70 centimetres; Height: 17.60 centimetres at rim
Inscription:
Inscription type: inscription Inscription position: 3 lines around the collar; 1 line around lower body Inscription language: Prakrit Inscription script: Kharoshthi Inscription transliteration: [1] saṃ 20 20 10 1 mas̱a arthamisiya sastehi 10 4 1 imeṇa gaḍ̱ig̱eṇa kamagulyaputra vag̱amareg̱a s̱a iśa khavadami kadalayig̱a vag̱amareg̱aviharammi thu[ba]mmi bhag̱avada śakyamuṇe śarira pariṭhaveti 
[2] imeṇa kuśalamuleṇa maharajarajatirajahuveṣkas̱a agrabhag̱ae bhavatu madapidara me puyae bhavatu bhradara me haṣthunaḥmareg̱as̱a puyae bhavatu yo ca me bhuya ṇatig̱amitrasaṃbhatig̱aṇa puyae bhavatu mahiya ca vag̱amareg̱as̱a agrabhag̱apaḍ̱iyaṃśae 
[3] bhavatu sarvasatvaṇa arogadakṣiṇae bhavatu avi ya ṇarag̱aparyata yava bhavagra yo atra aṃtara
a[ṃ]ḍajo jalayuga śaśvetiga arupyata sarviṇa puyae bhavatu mahiya ca rohaṇa sada sarviṇa
avaṣatrigaṇa saparivara ca agrabhagapaḍ̱iyaṃśae bhavatu mithyagas̱a ca agrabhaga bhavatu 
[4] eṣa vihara acaryaṇa mahasaṃghigaṇa parigraha Inscription translation: Baums 2012: [1] In the 51st year, in the month Artemisios, after 15 (days), at this time Vag̱amareg̱a, son of Kamagulya – he has made his abode here in Khavada – establishes in the Vag̱amareg̱a monastery in a stūpa a relic of the Lord, the Śākya sage. Inscription note: The inscription around the shoulder and the middle with four lines of punched Kharoshthi characters is dated to the year 51 of the first Kushan era and in the reign of Huvishka (2nd century AD). The characters are now picked out in white and are of smaller size along the shoulder than those in the shorter line below it. The inscription is of the Mahāsāṃghika sect and dedicates a relic of the Buddha in a stupa at Khavada, thought to correspond to modern Wardak, Wardak district, about 65 km south-west of Kabul.
Curators Comments:
E. Errington: Masson records that the relic deposit comprised 'a copper vessel with dotted Pehlevi [sic] inscription', which contained 'sundry relics' and '66 copper coins' (Masson MSS Eur. E161/VII, f. 27). The coins are identifiable from Masson's description of 'Indo-Scythic' coins and account of the finds in Wilson 1841, p.118 as Kushan coins of Wima Kadphises, Kanishka I and Huvishka, i.e. a similar combination of the same types as the 21 coins from Chahar Bagh Stupa 4 (see CM 1979,0215.21-41). 
The reliquary and associated finds were excavated in 1836 (MSS Eur. E161/VII, f.27).They were dispatched from Kabul by Masson in October 1836, but only reached London in March 1839, too late for more than a brief note in Wilson 1841.
